_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Enterprise Almeda Terminal
Enterprise Products Operating LLC
Executive Summary
Risk Management Plan
EPA Identifier:  1000 0006 5403

Accidental Release Prevention and Response

At Enterprise, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation
* An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
* An overview of our emergency response program
* An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Enterprise Products Almeda Terminal located in Harris County, Texas is owned by Enterprise GC, LP. and is operated by Enterprise Products Operating, LLC.  The terminal includes pipeline deliveries, pipeline receipts, truck racks, rail car racks and underground LPG storage wells leased from the Underground Storage Company.
    
The Houston 8" Pipeline brings propane from South Texas into Well 7 for storage.  Capability exists to bypass Well 7 and deliver propane directly to customers.

The Pasadena 6" Pipeline (Multi Purpose P/L) used to receive and deliver products in and out of the Terminal and bring products to and from customers.

The Pasadena 6" Pipeline is also used to transfer product to and from the Texas City Terminal.  

The 6" P/L normal transfers refiner

y grade butane (RGB), butane/butylene mix (BB Mix), and normal butane (NC4).

Almeda Terminal transfers LPG into and out of wells.
	Well 4 stores NC4 
	Well 7 stores C3 (propane) 
	Well 8 stores RGB 
	Well 17 stores BB Mix 

Brine water for the wells is used to aid in inbound and outbound movements.  The brine water is supplied by Texas Brine Company located inside the terminal at the N/W corner of the property.

Products received from trucks and rail cars goes into four onsite elevated bullet tanks and then injected into wells for storage.  Products are loaded from wells into trucks and rail cars for deliveries to customers.

The Almeda Terminal has the capability of loading and offloading eight rail cars at a time.

The LPG Loading and Unloading process and the LPG Cavern Storage are regulated by Federal OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  We have entered the facility as an RMP Program Level 1 facility.

The LPG Cavern Storage is considered storage incident to transportation and not subject to RMP regulations

Toxics

There are no toxic materials contained on site above the threshold limits.

Flammables

The Almeda Terminal was evaluated to determine if any regulated flammable or toxic substances exceeded the threshold quantity.  Enterprise identified the regulated substances and quantities kept on site based on facility knowledge.  Propane, RGP (refinery grade propane), Normal Butane, RGB (refinery grade butane), and BB Mix (butane/butylene mix) are all present above threshold quantities.

Offsite Consequence Analysis Results

The offsite consequence analysis will not be reflected in the executive summary but rather is reflected in the data components.  There are flammable substances on site and no toxic substances above the threshold quantity.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program

The following is a summary of the accidental release prevention program in place at Almeda Terminal.  The process at the facility is regulated by the Environmental

Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation (Program 1).  Release prevention is provided through the use of written operating procedures, employee training in written procedures, including normal operation and emergency release procedures, and in the design of safety and release prevention equipment installed at the terminal site.  In addition, a written safety program designed to comply with all applicable OSHA safety performance regulations is strictly enforced at all Enterprise facilities, including the Almeda Terminal facility.  As part of the Enterprise safety program, the facility utilizes procedures that are included in the Enterprise program, but may not specifically be required at non-PSM and/or RMP Program 1 facilities (e.g. Safe work practice training; safe work permitting and hot work permitting).

Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP covered processes at Almeda Terminal.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features

The Almeda Terminal has safety features on many units to help contain/control a release, to quickly detect a release and reduce the consequence of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered processes:

Release Detection

* Hydrocarbon (hazardous gas) detectors and alarms
* Flame detection equipment in the storage and loading areas
* Terminal video surveillance system

Release Containment and Control

* Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated).
* Automatic shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high pressure).
* Redundant equipment and instrumentation where advisable
* Storage tank internal emergency shut down and excess flow valves
* Well and equipment emergency shutdown (ESD) systems.
* Atmospheric relief devices
* Process relief valves that d

ischarge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases.
* Dual mechanical seals with seal failure alarms installed on hydrocarbon liquid pumps, where feasible.
* Storage tank manual shutoff valves
*Loading line excess flow valves

Release Mitigation

* Fire water system and monitors
* Hand-held fire extinguishers
* Personnel trained in emergency response and procedures.
* Personnel protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus, etc.)

Five Year Accident History

Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:

This facility has not had an accidental release in the last five years which meets the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10.

Emergency Procedures Information

The Enterprise Almeda Terminal maintains a written emergency procedure, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The procedures are for the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs. Employees receive training in emergency procedures.  The emergency procedure is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the plant facilities.

The overall emergency procedure program for the Enterprise Almeda Terminal is coordinated with the Harris County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials and industry representatives.  The Enterprise Almeda Terminal has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department).  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident,

if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Enterprise Almeda Terminal conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations, and also provides periodic refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the plant.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Almeda Terminal resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process.  Other recommendations for possible changes to improve safety come from periodic accident prevention program audits, incident investigations, or employee suggestions and recommendations.  The following changes are planned for implementation at the Almeda Terminal.

* Improved flare system header has been installed.
